prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Hydrogen Recombination Lines as Star-Formation Indicator

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require a sensitivity of ≈ 0.415 mJy for IRAS 17208-0014 (SNR=5). The line width is expected to be around 300 km/s, thus a coarse spectral resolution of 50 km/s is suitable. Since the largest angular size among our sources is ≈ 25 arcsec, the rest being much smaller, and since we are interested in line detection primarily, a spatial resolution of 4 arcsec was selected. The representative sky frequency of 94.96 GHz is based on the frequency of the H40α line. Based on the chosen spectral resolution and desired sensitivities, an observing time of 28.77 minutes, including overhead, was calculated.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Hydrogen Recombination Lines as Star-Formation Indicator

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require a sensitivity of ≈ 0.415 mJy for IRAS 14348-1447 (SNR=5). The line width is expected to be around 300 km/s, thus a coarse spectral resolution of 100 km/s is suitable. Since the largest angular size among our sources is ≈ 25 arcsec, the rest being much smaller, and since we are interested in line detection primarily, a spatial resolution of 4 arcsec was selected. The representative sky frequency of 91.43 GHz is based on the frequency of the H40α line. Based on the chosen spectral resolution and desired sensitivities, an observing time of 42 minutes, including overhead, was calculated.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require a sensitivity of ≈ 0.28 mJy for IRAS 10173+0828 (SNR=5). The line width is expected to be around 300 km/s, thus a coarse spectral resolution of 50 km/s is suitable. Since the largest angular size among our sources is ≈ 25 arcsec, the rest being much smaller, and since we are interested in line detection primarily, a spatial resolution of 4 arcsec was selected. The representative sky frequency of 94.39 GHz is based on the frequency of the H40α line. Based on the chosen spectral resolution and desired sensitivities, an observing time of 2.20 hours, including overhead, was calculated.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Hydrogen Recombination Lines as Star-Formation Indicator

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require a sensitivity of ≈ 0.28 mJy for IRAS 10173+0828 (SNR=5). The line width is expected to be around 300 km/s, thus a coarse spectral resolution of 100 km/s is suitable. Since the largest angular size among our sources is ≈ 25 arcsec, the rest being much smaller, and since we are interested in line detection primarily, a spatial resolution of 4 arcsec was selected. The representative sky frequency of 94.96 GHz is based on the frequency of the H40α line. Based on the chosen spectral resolution and desired sensitivities, an observing time of 1.08 hours, including overhead, was calculated.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe six nearby (z $<$ 0.1) starburst ULIRGs in the Hydrogen millimeter recombination lines (mm-RLs) H38$\alpha$, H40$\alpha$, H48$\beta$, H50$\beta$, H54$\gamma$, H64$\epsilon$, and the respective continuum. We like to thereby demonstrate an expected correlation between the mm-wavelength recombination line luminosity and their well-known far-infrared (FIR) luminosity, which would open up the possibility to use mm H recombination lines as a reliable measure of the massive star formation rates in distant galaxies. Unlike for cm radio-RLs, mm-RLs are much less contaminated by stimulated emission, and the lines are optically thin. Compared to UV or optical H-RLs, they do not suffer from dust extinction. Prior observations indicate a linear mm-RL-LFIR, but with three galaxies the basis is insufficient, which is mostly due to the lack of instrument sensitivity prior to ALMA.
